references: Miller, A.H. and R.C. Stebbins. 1964. The lives of desert animals in Joshua Tree National Monument. University of California Press, Berkeley and Los Angeles.
Wilson, D.E. and S. Ruff. 1999. The Smithsonian book of North American mammals. Washington, DC, Smithsonian Inst. Press. 750 p.
Zeiner, D. C., et al., editors. 1990. California's wildlife. Vol. II. Mammals. California Dept. Fish & Game, Sacramento. xi + 407 pp.
Grinnell, J. 1933. Review of the recent mammal fauna of California. Univ. Calif. Publ. Zool. 40:71-234.
Lackey, J.A. 1996. Chaetodipus fallax. The American Society of Mammalogists Mammalian Species No. 517, pp 1-6.
habitat_description:
Southwest:
Endemic to southern California, the San Diego Pocket Mouse is found in desert and coastal environments from sea level to 1800 meters in the the San Bernadino Mts. (Wilson and Ruff 1999, Zeiner et al. 1990). It is a "common resident of sandy herbaceous areas, usually in association with rocks or course gravel (Grinnell 1933, Miller and Stebbins 1964) in southwestern California. In San Diego Co., occurs mainly in arid coastal and desert border areas. Habitats
of the San Diego pocket mouse include coastal scrub, chamise-redshank chaparral, mixed
chaparral, sagebrush, desert wash, desert scrub, desert succulent shrub, pinyon-juniper,
and annual grassland." ([quoted directly from Brylski et al. 2007 CAWHR] based on Zeiner et al. 1990).
